qas.question: What did older operating systems use to mark the end of the text?
What is still the conventional use of the ETX code?

answers.text: to interrupt and halt a program via an input data stream, usually from a keyboard

qas.question: What else is the end-of-text code known as?
What did older operating systems use to mark control code?

plausible_answers.text: to interrupt and halt a program via an input data stream, usually from a keyboard

qas.question: What is still the conventional use of the EOF code?
What else does the end-of text code use to track file length?
Where does a control code usually come from?
What is using Z as the end of text analogous to?

context: Older operating systems such as TOPS-10, along with CP/M, tracked file length only in units of disk blocks and used <a0_0><b4_0>Control-Z<b4_0/> (SUB)<a0_0/> to mark the end of the actual text in the file. For this reason, EOF, or <a1_0>end-of-file<a1_0/>, was used colloquially and conventionally as a three-letter acronym for Control-Z instead of SUBstitute. The end-of-text code (ETX), also known as <a3_0><b6_0>Control-C<b6_0/><a3_0/>, was inappropriate for a variety of reasons, while using Z as the control code to end a file is analogous to <b8_0>it ending the alphabet<b8_0/> and serves as a very convenient mnemonic aid. A historically common and still prevalent convention uses the ETX code convention <a2_0><b5_0>to interrupt and halt a program via an input data stream, usually from <b7_0>a keyboard<b7_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/>.
